documentation.title: Would anything prevent a mortgage fixed to a property, portable between people in the UK?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Normally UK mortgages are fixed to a person, but portable/transferable between properties.

Disregarding the 80\+% of flats which are leasehold with no share of the freehold, is there anything in law preventing the opposite?

(Motivation/curiosity: I have seen this in other countries where 20\-30 year fixed rate mortgages are popular at the current low rates and don't give problems if people want to sell up, because they transfer the mortgage to the buyer of their property.

The only time a short/medium term mortgage would make sense there would be if interest rates were high and you expect them to drop – or to make up the price increase between the previous purchase price/mortgage and the current purchase price of a house if it is affordable and sensible to pay that off faster to pay less interest.)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A little looking around, for example, [here](http://www.mortgage-finder.co.uk/how-a-mortgage-works/how-a-mortgage-works.html), seem to indicate that the mortgage products currently on offer in the U.K. are primarily and in principle, at least, a matter of banking custom and practice (i.e. primarily economic decisions made by banks rather than a system mandated by regulators), rather than being mandated in all cases (and [porting is not always possible](http://www.moneysavingexpert.com/mortgages/porting-your-mortgage)). 

But, it also appears that there are [regulatory safe harbors](http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/borrowing/mortgages/11336328/Now-millions-face-mortgage-porting-woes-when-moving.html) and [institutional arrangements](https://www.cml.org.uk/news/news-and-views/378/) that make it hard to change that depart from a pure freedom of contract regime. 

For example, in the U.K., some loan underwriting standards are mandated by banking regulators who recently made those regulations more strict with the express mandate (ignored by the major banks for the most part) that these standards could not be applied to existing customers porting their mortgages to new properties.

An example of how customary practice can make it hard to change is that, while U.K. law permits fixed rate loans for the 10 to 30 year periods that are common in the U.S., when combined with portability, the economic risk faced by U.K. banks is much greater than in the U.S. where mortgages must be paid off when the property is sold and generally cannot be either assigned to the existing owner or ported with the seller. Because U.S. mortgages generally can't be ported or assumed by new owners, U.S. fixed rate mortgages are paid off, on average, every ten years, even though the home owner could choose to live in the same home and keep the mortgage for thirty years. This limits, in practice, the risk that U.S. banks face when they allow customers to lock into a low thirty year fixed interest rate. (U.S. reformers tend to focus on making loans assumable and limiting the availability of prepayment penalties and wouldn't even dream of trying to establish portable mortgages.)

Similarly, while U.K. law does not require pre\-payment penalties, the economic bargain involved in a U.K. mortgage has banks relying on people not pre\-paying their loans or paying pre\-payment penalties in order to establish the creditworthiness of the bank to regulators and third parties.

So, while it might be possible in theory to allow an assignable version of a U.S. mortgage which is tied to the property and not the person, in the U.K., one would have to simultaneously change other aspects of the transaction and the way that banks estimate their cash flow to meet their own obligations, for this change to work, something that would probably require regulatory cooperation to work in practice.

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the UK mortgage market, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the nature of mortgage products and their transferability?

A) UK mortgage products are entirely regulated by law, with no flexibility for banks to offer different terms.

B) UK mortgages are always portable between properties due to strict regulatory requirements.

C) UK mortgage products are primarily determined by banking custom and practice, with some regulatory influence.

D) UK mortgages cannot be transferred or ported under any circumstances.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The information provided indicates that UK mortgage products are primarily determined by banking custom and practice, rather than being strictly mandated by regulators. However, there are regulatory safe harbors and institutional arrangements that influence these products. This means banks have some flexibility in their offerings, but are also constrained by regulatory frameworks and industry norms.

Answer A is incorrect because UK mortgage products are not entirely regulated by law. There is room for banks to make economic decisions about their offerings.

Answer B is incorrect because while portability is a common feature of UK mortgages, it is not always possible or guaranteed due to various factors including regulatory changes and bank policies.

Answer D is incorrect because UK mortgages can often be ported or transferred, although this is not universally true for all mortgage products or situations.

documentation.title: How to reconcile opposing legal answers?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: [A fraud in the terms of use](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/46745/a-fraud-in-the-terms-of-use) has two opposing answers: one said it **was** a fraud, while some said it was **not**.

How do I reconcile those answers?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Law is more like sport than mathematics
---------------------------------------

You don’t know how it will turn out until you play the game.

If a case goes to trial it’s because at both sides believe they can win. Both sides probably have good reasons for their belief. At least one of them is wrong.

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In legal matters, why might there be conflicting opinions on whether something constitutes fraud, even among legal experts?

A) Legal interpretations are always clear-cut and unambiguous
B) Fraud cases are typically settled out of court, so expert opinions don't matter
C) The law is open to interpretation and outcomes can depend on how arguments are presented in court
D) Only the judge's opinion matters in fraud cases, not legal experts

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. As the documentation suggests, law is more like a sport than mathematics. It's not always clear-cut, and different interpretations can lead to different opinions, even among experts. The outcome often depends on how arguments are presented in court, which is why both sides in a legal dispute might believe they can win.

Option A is incorrect because legal interpretations are often not clear-cut, as evidenced by the conflicting answers in the example.

Option B is false because expert opinions do matter in legal cases, whether they go to court or not.

Option D is incorrect because while a judge's opinion is crucial, legal experts' opinions are important in shaping arguments and understanding complex legal issues.

This question tests understanding of the nature of legal interpretation and the uncertainty inherent in legal proceedings.

documentation.title: Do I really have to Open Source my project?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I'm currently working on a software which uses another software under the [GPL version 3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_General_Public_License#Version_3) license:
<https://github.com/ViaVersion/ViaVersion/blob/dev/LICENSE>

Now someone just came to me and said I have to Open Source my project or I can get in trouble.

I'm not quite sure... But I thought I don't need to do this, because my project is completely private. I will not publish this project whatsoever.

Only me and 2 friends use my software.

Do I really have to Open Source my project?

And if yes, is it enough to just publish the code parts using the software?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You need to know two things about the GPL:

* The GPL is a license which requires that when you distribute binaries, you distribute the source code with them (binaries being the things you can directly run)
* The GPL is *copyleft* \- any project using something licensed under the GPL must also be licensed under the GPL

The easiest way to comply with the first point is to simply make the software open source by making it available to all online. Many, if not all, large projects licensed under the GPL do this.

The other way of complying is to simply give anyone else who has a copy of the binaries, or who makes use of them, a copy of the source code. In your case, all you need to do is send your friends a copy of the source. As long as no one else uses this project, I think you satisfy the requirements of the license.

You must, however, also license your code under the GPL. This means, as mentioned in the comments, that you must somehow make your friends aware that if they redistribute your code, they must also do so under the terms of the GPL. This can be as simple as including a file called `LICENSE` in the root directory of the source code, containing a copy of the text of the GPL.

This further means that your friends will be able to share your code with other people without letting you know. You could politely ask them not to, but you can't stop them.

(That said, you have no reason to be worried \- only big breaches of license misuse by large companies ever tend to get chased up. However, it's great that you want to be careful about this! Software licensing, especially FOSS licensing, is very important.)

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A software developer is creating a private project that uses a library licensed under GPL version 3. The project is only used by the developer and two friends. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the developer's obligations under the GPL?

A) The developer must immediately make the entire project open source and publicly available online.

B) The developer doesn't need to do anything since the project is private and not distributed publicly.

C) The developer must provide the source code to the two friends who use the software and license the project under GPL, but doesn't need to make it publicly available.

D) The developer only needs to open source the specific parts of the code that directly interact with the GPL-licensed library.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The GPL v3 license requires that when you distribute software (even to a limited audience like friends), you must provide the source code to those recipients. Additionally, the copyleft nature of GPL means that any project using GPL-licensed code must also be licensed under GPL. The developer doesn't need to make the project publicly available online, but must provide the source code to the two friends who use it and license the entire project under GPL. This ensures that if the friends decide to redistribute the code, they must do so under the terms of the GPL.

documentation.title: Non US company raised equity by issuing shares to non accredited investors,does re-domiciliation to Delaware cause retroactive breach of US laws?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: As per the title I would like to know if anybody knows what happens if a foreign non \-\- U.S. company ( offshore ) raises equity by advertising and soliciting investors included but not limited to people who are not accredited investors per U.S. definition . 

Raising equity by issuing shares to non\-accredited investors is not a violation in the offshore Jurisdiction as it isn't advertising and soliciting to investors . 

My question is : what happens if the aforementioned offshore company re\-domiciliates to U.S. , specifically Delaware ? Does re\-domiciliation imply a retroactive breach of US laws with regards to said equity raise ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The question does not provide all of the necessary information.

The sale of securities not registered with the SEC that are issued by a foreign company to a non\-accredited investor in the U.S. are a violation of the Securities Act of 1933 which governs public offerings of securities under U.S. law. There are exceptions to this rule, that don't obviously apply in the circumstances describe by the original post, but the mere fact that the issuer is not organized or based in the U.S. does not mean that it is exempt from the '33 Act.

On the other hand, if the non\-accredited investors of the foreign issuer were all non\-U.S. persons, there would be no securities fraud violations under U.S. law or the law of any U.S. state when the securities were issued.

> what happens if the aforementioned offshore company re\-domiciliates to
>  U.S., specifically Delaware? Does re\-domiciliation imply a
>  retroactive breach of US laws with regards to said equity raise?

The re\-incorporation of the foreign issuer in the State of Delaware in the United States would not be a retroactive violation of the Securities Act of 1933, which governs public offerings of securities in the United States, because a change in a corporation's place of organization does not constitute a public offering under the '33 Act.

But, as noted above, if the foreign issuer of the securities sold securities to U.S. investors prior to the relocation and without registering the sale with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, those sales could have been '33 Act violations in the first instance, despite the fact that it was a foreign issuer. And, re\-incorporation of the foreign issuer in Delaware might very well bring the company's previous '33 Act violations, if any, to the attention of the SEC even if the SEC had not previously been aware of those violations.

But, upon relocation to Delaware, the formerly foreign issuer would, going forward, be subject to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934\. This act requires companies that are listed on a U.S. stock exchange, or are organized in the U.S. with [more than $10 million in assets whose securities are held by more than 500 owners](https://www.sec.gov/answers/about-lawsshtml.html) to file annual and other periodic reports, and to comply with other regulatory requirements applicable only to publicly held companies.

3.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the provided information:

Question: A foreign company based in the Cayman Islands has raised equity by selling shares to non-accredited investors globally, including some U.S. citizens. The company is now considering re-domiciling to Delaware. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications of this situation?

A) The company's previous share sales to non-accredited U.S. investors were legal because the company was foreign at the time, and re-domiciling to Delaware will have no impact on the legality of those sales.

B) Re-domiciling to Delaware will automatically make the previous share sales to non-accredited U.S. investors illegal, exposing the company to immediate SEC penalties.

C) The previous share sales to non-accredited U.S. investors may have violated the Securities Act of 1933, regardless of the company's foreign status, and re-domiciling to Delaware could bring these potential violations to the SEC's attention.

D) Re-domiciling to Delaware will retroactively legalize any previous share sales to non-accredited U.S. investors, protecting the company from SEC scrutiny.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The sale of securities to non-accredited U.S. investors by a foreign company, without proper SEC registration, may violate the Securities Act of 1933, even if the company is foreign. Re-domiciling to Delaware doesn't create a retroactive violation, but it could draw the SEC's attention to any existing violations. Additionally, once re-domiciled, the company would become subject to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, requiring it to comply with U.S. reporting and regulatory requirements for public companies going forward.

documentation.title: Do countries that are not members of the Berne Convention still enjoy the benefits it provides?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works, usually known as the Berne Convention, is an international agreement governing copyright, which was first accepted in Berne, Switzerland, in 1886\.

Although widely recognized around the world, there are still some countries that are not signatories to the Berne Convention. For example: Palestine, Somalia, Iran, Iraq, etc.

What would happen if an Iranian artist or designer's work is plagiarized by an American company, would they still be protected by the Berne Convention?

What if the aforementioned creative individual later moves to a country that is a member of the Berne Convention? Would there be retrospective application?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No
--

The [Berne Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berne_Convention) requires member states to afford copyright protection equal to their own to works from *other* member states. A work first published only in non\-member state(s) and by citizen(s) of non\-member state(s) is not required to be given such protection but such protection is not prohibited either.

A work can not acquire copyright retrospectively if it didn’t have it on creation.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An Iranian artist creates a unique painting while living in Iran. Later, the artist moves to France, a signatory of the Berne Convention. Shortly after, a U.S. company uses the painting without permission in their advertising. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding copyright protection for the artist's work?

A) The painting is automatically protected under the Berne Convention once the artist moves to France.
B) The U.S. company is obligated to provide copyright protection equal to that of works created by U.S. citizens.
C) The painting has no copyright protection in the U.S. because it was created in a non-member country of the Berne Convention.
D) The U.S. may choose to offer copyright protection, but is not required to do so under the Berne Convention.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The Berne Convention requires member states to provide copyright protection to works from other member states. However, works first published in non-member states (like Iran) by citizens of non-member states are not required to be given such protection. The U.S., as a member of the Berne Convention, is not obligated to provide copyright protection for the Iranian artist's work, even after the artist moves to France. However, the Convention does not prohibit member states from offering such protection if they choose to do so. The artist's relocation to France does not retroactively grant Berne Convention protections to works created before the move.

documentation.title: Getting ripped off by a vending machine
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I bought something from a vending machine and it only gave me 6 dollars in change when it should've given me 9\. This is stealing and I was very unhappy but didn't want to waste my time asking the owner to get my $3 back because it would be a hassle and 20 minutes of my time is very valuable, worth much more than $3\. Can I ask the manager for 20 dollars refund because of the cost of my time?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can ask the manager, but you probably won't get. 

Your legal entitlement is to $3 of compensatory damages period and maybe court costs if any if a lawsuit is brought. 

Without an intent to steal (which is unlikely) it isn't theft, it is just a breach of a contract for the sale of goods, or unjust enrichment.

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A customer purchases an item from a vending machine for $12, inserting a $20 bill. The machine dispenses the item but only returns $6 in change instead of the correct $8. The customer decides not to immediately pursue the $2 discrepancy due to time constraints. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the legal situation and potential remedies?

A) The vending machine owner has committed theft and can be criminally prosecuted for the $2 discrepancy.

B) The customer is entitled to sue for $20 to compensate for both the $2 error and the time spent pursuing the claim.

C) The customer's legal entitlement is limited to the $2 in compensatory damages, plus potential court costs if a lawsuit is filed.

D) The vending machine malfunction constitutes intentional fraud, entitling the customer to punitive damages.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, the customer's legal entitlement is limited to the actual monetary loss ($2 in this case) as compensatory damages. Additionally, if a lawsuit were to be filed, the customer might be able to recover court costs. The situation described is likely to be considered a breach of contract for the sale of goods or unjust enrichment, rather than theft or fraud, especially if there was no intent to steal. The customer cannot claim additional compensation for the value of their time spent pursuing the claim, nor are they entitled to punitive damages in this scenario. Options A, B, and D incorrectly characterize the legal nature of the situation or overstate the potential remedies available to the customer.

documentation.title: Royalty split between a singer/songwriter and composer/producer
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have written the lyrics to a song, came up with the melody and paid a composer to translate it into musical notes and create the song (with instruments). I paid for his services. Now, I want to launch it through a music distribution platform. I am responsible to decide on the royalty split. What royalty split should I consider? Thanks a lot!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Who owns the copyright?
-----------------------

It’s clear that you own the copyright in the lyrics because they are solely your own work. However, the ownership of the music is less clear \- your melody, the composer’s arrangement and performance. Do you own it or do they or is it a joint work?

What did you put in the contract with the composer about copyright? As an independent contractor, the composer would own the copyright in their contribution making it a joint work unless the contract provided otherwise.

If you own it, the royalties are all yours. If it’s a joint work then a) you need the other author’s permission to do this and b) the split is whatever you agree to.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: An aspiring songwriter, Alice, writes lyrics and comes up with a melody for a song. She then hires Bob, a composer, to translate the melody into musical notes and create the full song with instruments. Alice pays Bob for his services but doesn't specify anything about copyright in their contract. Alice wants to launch the song through a music distribution platform. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the copyright and royalty situation?

A) Alice owns full copyright to both lyrics and music, and can decide on royalty split entirely on her own.

B) Alice owns copyright to the lyrics, while Bob owns copyright to the music, requiring them to agree on royalty split.

C) Alice and Bob likely have a joint work, where Alice owns copyright to the lyrics and they share copyright of the music, necessitating mutual agreement on royalty split.

D) Bob owns full copyright to both lyrics and music since he created the final product, and Alice needs his permission for distribution.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Based on the information provided, this scenario most closely aligns with a joint work situation. Alice clearly owns the copyright to the lyrics as they are solely her creation. However, the music copyright is less straightforward. Alice came up with the melody, but Bob arranged it and added instrumentation. Without a specific contract clause addressing copyright, Bob, as an independent contractor, would likely retain some rights to his contribution. This makes the music portion a joint work, requiring both parties to agree on royalty splits and distribution decisions. Option C accurately reflects this complex situation, emphasizing the need for mutual agreement on royalties and recognizing the shared nature of the music copyright.

documentation.title: Sexting and age
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: This question is about [sexting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexting) (a person sending a sexually explicit image of themself to a recipient by electronic means). 

When can the recipient get in trouble with the law if the person sending the naked picture is less than 18 years of age (for example 16\)? 

It’s my understanding that if a person randomly emails or texts a naked picture of herself then the recipient isn’t automatically a criminal just because they are in possession of child pornography. If someone requests a nude photo from someone who is beneath the age of 18, does the fact that they requested make it so that they can be charged with child pornography? What if the sender lied about her age?

For example: say Jane and Joe are friends. Joe is 21\. Jane has told Joe she is 19 but is actually 16\. If Jane sends Joe naked pictures of herself through Facebook chat, could Joe get in trouble? Does it matter if Joe asked for them or not? Can Joe do anything to legally make amends? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In NSW Australia this is covered by Division 15A of the [Crimes Act 1900](http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act/ca190082/s91fa.html) which deals with Child Abuse Material. Under Section 91FA a "child" means a person who is *under* the age of 16 years \- the situation you describe would be between consenting adults in NSW. “Child abuse material” can be text or images that are sexually explicit and would be “offensive” to a normal person (which means offensive to the particular jury)

Assuming Jane is 15 or less, however, *prima facie* the image would be child abuse material and under Section 91H "A person who produces, disseminates or possesses child abuse material is guilty of an offence." The punishment is up to 10 years in jail.

Section 91H provides a number of defences, the most relevant to the circumstances you describe being:

1. that the defendant did not know, and could not reasonably be expected to have known, that he or she produced, disseminated or possessed (as the case requires) child abuse material.
2. that the material concerned came into the defendant’s possession unsolicited and the defendant, as soon as he or she became aware of its nature, took reasonable steps to get rid of it. (for possession only)

If, considering **all** the circumstances of the relationship, Joe doesn't know and could not reasonably be expected to know Jane's age then he can use the defence under S91H(1\). If he did not request the picture and as soon as he was aware of Jane's age, deleted it, then he can use the defence under S91H(2\).

The outcome is not so rosy for Jane: she is guilty of both production and dissemination of child abuse material and (assuming she knows how old she is) faces up to 10 years in jail (14 if she is under 14\) and registration on the Sex Offenders List for life. It is admittedly unlikely in the circumstances that the state would prosecute her and, if they did, it is very likely that the judge would rule that no conviction be recorded.

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In NSW, Australia, 20-year-old Alex receives an unsolicited sexually explicit image from 15-year-old Sam through a messaging app. Sam had previously told Alex they were 18. Alex is shocked upon learning Sam's real age and immediately deletes the image. Under the NSW Crimes Act 1900, what is Alex's legal situation?

A) Alex is automatically guilty of possessing child abuse material and faces up to 10 years in jail.
B) Alex has no legal liability as long as they can prove Sam lied about their age.
C) Alex may have a valid defense under Section 91H if they can demonstrate they couldn't reasonably have known Sam's age and took immediate action to delete the image.
D) Alex is required to report the incident to authorities or face charges of failing to report child abuse.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the NSW Crimes Act 1900, Alex may have a valid defense under Section 91H. This section provides two relevant defenses:
1. The defendant did not know and could not reasonably be expected to have known they possessed child abuse material.
2. The material came into the defendant's possession unsolicited, and they took reasonable steps to get rid of it as soon as they became aware of its nature.

In this scenario, Alex meets both these criteria:
- They were led to believe Sam was 18, so they couldn't reasonably have known they were receiving material from a minor.
- The image was unsolicited, and Alex deleted it immediately upon learning Sam's real age.

Options A and B are incorrect because mere possession of such material is prima facie an offense, but defenses are available. Option D is incorrect as there's no mandatory reporting requirement in this situation for individuals not in positions of authority or care.

documentation.title: International student - registering a marriage in the UK with a foreign citizen
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am an international graduate student in the UK on a Tier 4 student visa. My partner is a German citizen and currently lives in Germany. We are planning to get married. Are we allowed to register our marriage in the UK and if yes how? Most guides assume that I am British or that my partner is British and are written accordingly but this is not the case.

Specifcally, according to [this link](https://www.gov.uk/marriages-civil-partnerships/give-notice), we both to "give notice" of our marriage. Can my partner do this while visiting the UK as a tourist? Can I do this while on a student visa?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: To get married in the UK, since Brexit, all citizens that aren't living in the UK, except for settled EU and Irish citizens, must apply for a [Marriage Visitor Visa](https://www.gov.uk/marriage-visa), even to give notice

> **Non\-visa nationals who have not applied for a Marriage/Civil Partnership visit visa to come to the UK to marry or enter into a civil partnership**  
> 
> See: paragraph V 1\.1(b) and V 1\.3(a) of Appendix V: Visitor.

> Non\-visa nationals who are seeking entry to visit the UK
> to marry or enter into a civil partnership, or to give notice of an
> intention to marry or form a civil partnership, who do not hold a
> Marriage/Civil Partnership visit visa must be refused entry.

[Page 62 of the case worker guidance for visit visa](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/visit-guidance)

This only applies to your partner, and not to you, as you aren't the holder of a visitor visa, you don't need further special permission to marry on a Tier 4

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: An international student from Japan on a Tier 4 visa in the UK wants to marry their partner who is a Spanish citizen living in Spain. Which of the following statements is correct regarding their ability to get married in the UK?

A) Both the student and their Spanish partner can give notice of marriage while the partner is visiting the UK as a tourist.

B) The Spanish partner needs to apply for a Marriage Visitor Visa, but the student can give notice of marriage with their current Tier 4 visa.

C) Both the student and their Spanish partner need to apply for special marriage visas before they can give notice of marriage in the UK.

D) The student needs to return to Japan and the Spanish partner needs to return to Spain before they can apply to get married in the UK.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the information provided, since Brexit, all non-UK residents who are not settled EU or Irish citizens must apply for a Marriage Visitor Visa to give notice of marriage in the UK. This applies to the Spanish partner, who is an EU citizen but not residing in the UK. However, the international student on a Tier 4 visa does not need additional permission to marry while in the UK on their current visa. Option A is incorrect because the Spanish partner cannot give notice as a tourist. Option C is incorrect because the student doesn't need a special marriage visa. Option D is incorrect as neither party needs to return to their home country to apply for marriage in the UK.

documentation.title: Claiming collaborative work as individual
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: What is (if any) the offense for claiming a piece of collaborative work as an individual work.

More concretely, if a thesis was the collaborative effort of multiple personnel but one decided to claim that it was his/her own work, what offense did he/she commit? (copyright? theft?)

Furthermore, say said person contributed vastly more than the others, will his claim be justified / more justifiable?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One possibility is that the person submitting the thesis can have their degree revoked. This is not strictly a legal matter, rather it is a matter between the student and their university, where the university can, after a process, revoke the degree. The grounds would be a violation of university rules pertaining to requirements for the degree, specifically the part where the student must submit a thesis representing "independent research". The exact wording of the requirement is obviously institution\-dependent, and of course no university requires completely autonomous and isolated research and writing in the production of a thesis. It would be rather off\-topic though fascinating to collects anecdotes on variation between institutions on what degree of collaboration is deemed acceptable. From the legal perspective, the student whose degree is revoked could attempt to sue the university for the revocation, since the student has a property interest in the degree, but generally university proceedings are held by the courts to be valid.

Another way to "claim" a work as your own is with respect to copyright. In that case, though, there has to be more than vague collaboration, there has to be actual co\-authorship. The basic legal idea is that when multiple authors write a work, they jointly own the work (the work is called a "joint work"). The basic definition of a joint work under 17 USC 101 is "a work prepared by two or more authors with the intention that their contributions be merged into inseparable or interdependent parts of a unitary whole". Sharing of ideas or lab results doesn't make something a joint work, there has to be actual co\-writing.

The US Copyright Office interprets that as meaning that authors have equal rights to the work (an undivided ownership share): in other words, any author can grant permission to publish, and a copyright license of transfer of rights does not have to be agreed on by both authors. However, profits are to be shared equally among the authors, in the same way that joint partners in a business venture share the profits of their business. This is so even if one author writes 90% of the work and the other one writes 10%.

This can then lead to a legal problem between the publisher and the non\-signatory author. Typically, when a work is published, the publisher obtains from the contributor either a license to reproduce, or else a transfer of copyright, which allows the publisher to reproduce the work. Such agreements typically contain a clause where the contributor warrants that they have the right to transfer / license and that they are the sole author, or else the co\-authors have been identified in the agreement (in which case the publisher pursues each author to get a signature on an agreement form). And there is almost surely an indemnification clause, saying that the contributor will indemnify the publisher against any infringement claims. Which is another way of saying, if it turns out that the contributor does not have the right to fully assign copyright to the work and the publisher gets sued, the contributor must cover the publisher's legal costs and possible losses from a judgment. As a co\-author, you cannot grant an exclusive license (as some publishers will require).

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A graduate student, Alex, submits a thesis that was largely a collaborative effort with two other students, but Alex claims it as entirely their own work. The university discovers this and revokes Alex's degree. Alex decides to sue the university. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this situation?

A) The university's decision will likely be overturned because Alex has absolute ownership of the degree once it's granted.

B) The court will likely side with Alex if they can prove they contributed more than 50% of the work.

C) The university's decision will likely be upheld by the court, as academic institutions have broad discretion in enforcing their own rules.

D) Alex can claim copyright infringement against the university for revoking the degree based on joint authorship laws.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Courts generally respect the autonomy of academic institutions to enforce their own rules and standards, including those related to academic integrity. The revocation of a degree for misrepresenting collaborative work as individual work would likely be seen as within the university's purview. 

Answer A is incorrect because while a degree does represent a property interest, it's not absolute and can be revoked for valid reasons.

Answer B is incorrect because the proportion of work contributed doesn't justify misrepresenting collaborative work as individual, especially in an academic context where proper attribution is crucial.

Answer D is incorrect because copyright infringement is not applicable in this scenario. The issue at hand is academic misconduct, not a copyright dispute.

documentation.title: How many people can legally contest a given mandate at the same time in the United States?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: How many people can legally contest a given mandate at the same time in the United States? A lot of companies intend to legally contest the vaccine mandate that was announced by Biden. I am wondering if judges are allowed to reject some legal contests if too many individuals are contesting it.

### Sources

* ["State AG Promises Court Challenge of Federal Vaccine Mandate"](https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/montana/articles/2021-09-10/state-ag-promises-court-challenge-of-federal-vaccine-mandate) from *US News*
* ["A vaccine law expert explains the 3 most likely legal challenges Biden's federal vaccine mandate might face"](https://www.businessinsider.com/vaccine-law-expert-explains-likely-legal-challenges-biden-vaccine-mandate-2021-9) from *Insider*
* ["Current constitutional issues related to vaccine mandates"](https://constitutioncenter.org/blog/current-constitutional-issues-related-to-vaccine-mandates) from *Constitution Daily*
* ["Biden is requiring the vast majority of federal workers to get vaccinated or face disciplinary measures"](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/09/09/us/politics/biden-vaccine-federal-workers.html) from the *NY Times*

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As many parties as have standing. The First Amendment protects the right to petition for redress of grievances, so any limitation on that right would be highly disfavored.

When there's a rush of cases like this, though, there are a few option for dealing with them. For instance, a plaintiff may seek class certification, permitting him to stand in for similarly situated parties so they don't need to litigate themselves, or a court may consolidate the cases if they are sufficiently similar.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the context of multiple legal challenges to a federal vaccine mandate, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the courts' ability to manage numerous lawsuits?

A) Judges can reject legal contests if too many individuals are challenging the mandate simultaneously.

B) The First Amendment prohibits any limitation on the number of parties that can challenge the mandate.

C) Courts have no mechanisms to efficiently handle a large number of similar cases against the mandate.

D) Courts may use methods such as class certification or case consolidation to manage multiple similar challenges.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Option D is correct because it accurately reflects the information provided in the source. While there is no specific limit on how many parties can contest a mandate, courts have methods to efficiently manage multiple similar cases. These include class certification, where one plaintiff represents a group of similarly situated parties, and case consolidation, where multiple similar cases are combined for more efficient processing.

Option A is incorrect because judges cannot simply reject valid legal contests due to high volume. This would violate the right to petition for redress of grievances.

Option B, while touching on the importance of the First Amendment, overstates the case by suggesting there can be no limitations whatsoever.

Option C is incorrect because it contradicts the information provided about methods courts can use to handle multiple similar cases efficiently.

documentation.title: Can information about a drug - trade name, interactions, etc. - be copyright protected?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Can information about a drug, like its trade name, interactions, pharmacokinetics, etc., be copyright protected, or is the information free for use in a commercial sense?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The information itself is not copyrighted.

* The fact that a drug is an "antagonist platelet aggregation inhibitor" is not copyrighted.
* The fact that a drug is indicated for "reducing the risk of thrombotic stroke in patients who have experienced stroke precursors or who have had a completed thrombotic stroke" is not copyrighted.

The label author might make certain choices about how to express those facts, though. "\[C]hoices as to selection and arrangement, so long as they are made independently by the compiler and entail a minimal degree of creativity, are sufficiently original" to trigger copyright protection. [Feist Pubs., Inc. v. Rural Tel. Svc. Co., Inc.](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/499/340/case.html).

The FDA has created regulations concerning the selection and arrangement of facts in the context of prescription drug labeling. ([An Introduction to the
Improved FDA Prescription
Drug Labeling](http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Training/ForHealthProfessionals/UCM090796.pdf), [21 CFR Part 201](https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfCFR/CFRSearch.cfm?CFRPart=201), [Consolidated Final Rule and Changes](http://www.fda.gov/OHRMS/DOCKETS/98fr/06-545.pdf))

Thus in the context of prescription drug labeling, the selection and arrangement of facts are not "made independently by the compiler".

The only things this leaves for copyright protection are:

* literal word\-for\-word copying of phrases where there are suitable alternative ways of expressing the same fact, or
* other expression not regulated by the FDA.

And, if a certain mode of expressing a particular fact has become industry standard (even if there are alternatives), the *scènes à faire* doctrine either precludes copyrightability or is a defense to infringement, depending on your district.

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A pharmaceutical company is developing a mobile app that provides information about various drugs, including their trade names, interactions, and pharmacokinetics. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the copyright protection of drug information in this context?

A) All information about drugs, including trade names and interactions, is automatically copyright protected and cannot be used without permission.

B) Only the specific wording used to describe drug information is potentially copyrightable, while the factual information itself is not protected by copyright.

C) The FDA regulations on drug labeling make it impossible for any drug information to be copyright protected.

D) As long as the app developers rearrange the order of the drug information, they can freely use any content from existing drug labels without copyright concerns.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The factual information about drugs (such as their interactions, pharmacokinetics, and indications) is not copyrightable. However, the specific way this information is expressed might be protected by copyright if it involves creative choices in selection and arrangement that are not dictated by FDA regulations.

Answer A is incorrect because factual information about drugs is not automatically copyright protected.

Answer C is overly broad. While FDA regulations limit the scope of copyright protection for drug labels, they don't completely eliminate the possibility of copyright protection for certain aspects of the content.

Answer D is incorrect because merely rearranging information doesn't necessarily avoid copyright infringement if the specific wording is copied and that wording is protected by copyright.

The key point is that while facts themselves are not copyrightable, the specific expression of those facts may be, but this is limited in the context of drug information due to FDA regulations and the need for standardization in the industry.

documentation.title: Is it legal to record an episode of a TV series or a movie?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is it legal to record an episode of a TV series or a movie? Isn't it considered as making an illegal copy of the movie? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: At least for the US, there's a good overview in The Atlantic of the SCOTUS benchmark case concerning home recording, still applicable in these days of DVDs and streaming content and torrents and thepiratebay.org: 

> ...the Supreme Court's decision to allow home recording in the
>  landmark 1984 case, Universal Studios vs. Sony Corporation of America,
>  went 5\-4; one justice flipping and you wouldn't have to imagine that
>  alternate reality because you'd be living it. See [http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/01/the\-court\-case\-that\-almost\-made\-it\-illegal\-to\-tape\-tv\-shows/251107/](http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/01/the-court-case-that-almost-made-it-illegal-to-tape-tv-shows/251107/)

The case revolved around whether recording a television program was "fair use" under copyright law. 

> Fair use is a legal doctrine that promotes freedom of expression by
>  permitting the unlicensed use of copyright\-protected works in certain
>  circumstances. See [https://www.copyright.gov/fair\-use/more\-info.html](https://www.copyright.gov/fair-use/more-info.html)

So yes, you can make yourself a copy, because 

> "that the making of individual copies of complete television shows for
>  purposes of time shifting does not constitute copyright infringement,
>  but is fair use."
>  <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_Corp._of_America_v._Universal_City_Studios,_Inc>.

Time shifting as in watching it later, and much later again, as long as you don't distribute that copy, sell admission to watching it, and anything else reasonable when it comes to only you using the copy.

12.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the landmark 1984 case Universal Studios vs. Sony Corporation of America, the Supreme Court ruled on the legality of home recording of television programs. Which of the following statements best describes the outcome and its implications?

A) The court ruled that home recording was illegal, setting a precedent against personal copies of copyrighted material.

B) The court decision was unanimous in favor of allowing home recording as fair use.

C) The court ruled 5-4 that home recording for the purpose of time-shifting constitutes fair use and is not copyright infringement.

D) The court determined that home recording is only legal if the content creator explicitly permits it.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The Supreme Court ruled 5-4 in favor of allowing home recording as fair use in the 1984 case Universal Studios vs. Sony Corporation of America. This decision established that making individual copies of complete television shows for the purpose of time-shifting (watching later) does not constitute copyright infringement but falls under fair use. The ruling was narrow (5-4), indicating it was a contentious issue. This decision set an important precedent for personal use of copyrighted material, allowing individuals to record broadcasts for later viewing without violating copyright laws, as long as they don't distribute or profit from these recordings.

documentation.title: Implications with states that classify traffic infractions as misdemeanors
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: It appears that some states, for example, Wyoming, classify most traffic infractions as *misdemeanors*.

Does it imply that someone who has committed a 5 mph speeding in such a state is technically a full fledged *criminal*, whereas another person doing the same in a state like California never is?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your question assumes that there is a universal, legal definition of "criminal." Since there is not, it can't be answered.

Infractions, misdemeanors, and felonies are all criminal offenses defined by criminal law. There may be different implications involved in being found guilty of an infraction rather than a misdemeanor, but it's not the case that one of them makes you a "criminal" and the other does not.

13.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In the context of traffic violations and criminal law, which of the following statements is most accurate?

A) A person who commits a minor speeding violation in Wyoming is legally considered a criminal, while someone committing the same offense in California is not.

B) Infractions, misdemeanors, and felonies are distinct categories, with only felonies being considered criminal offenses.

C) The classification of traffic violations varies by state, but this variation does not inherently determine whether an offender is considered a "criminal" in a universal legal sense.

D) States that classify traffic infractions as misdemeanors are legally obligated to treat offenders as full-fledged criminals in all aspects of the law.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because it accurately reflects the nuanced reality of how traffic violations are treated across different states. The question highlights that some states, like Wyoming, may classify minor traffic infractions as misdemeanors, while others, like California, may not. However, this classification difference doesn't create a universal definition of "criminal."

Answer A is incorrect because it oversimplifies the issue and assumes a universal definition of "criminal" based solely on state classification.

Answer B is wrong because it incorrectly states that only felonies are considered criminal offenses, when in fact infractions, misdemeanors, and felonies are all defined under criminal law.

Answer D is incorrect because it exaggerates the implications of classifying infractions as misdemeanors and assumes a blanket treatment of offenders that isn't necessarily true.

The correct answer acknowledges the variation in state laws while also recognizing that these classifications don't determine a universal legal definition of "criminal."

documentation.title: Is there any grace period for worldwide trademark protection like patent?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: When it comes to patent, it seems like there is a 12 months period where we can file International Patent from the date of provisional patent.

I have a trademark in the US. I would like to go for international trademark once I raise some money from Investors. 

Is there any such grace period available for international trademark?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is no such thing as a global trademark. There are trademarks in different countries, and when you start doing business in those countries you can file to obtain a trademark in those countries.

For example, Ivanka Trump's fashion line had U.S. trademarks and has been in the process of obtaining Chinese trademarks over the last few years since she has started doing business in China.

There is no particular timeline for obtaining a trademark. Simply using it gives rise to common law trademark rights without any filing in many countries in the places and markets where you use it, and you can't obtain a trademark until you are using it in commerce in a country or imminently about to do so. 

But, unlike a patent which goes into the public domain if you don't timely perfect it with a patent filing, a trademark can be obtained at any time before someone else is granted the same trademark in the some geographic area in which you seek one, in the market for goods or services of the same type as you are seeking.

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A company has been using its trademark in the United States for 2 years and now wants to expand internationally. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding international trademark protection?

A) The company has a 12-month grace period from the US filing date to file for international trademark protection.

B) The company can file for a global trademark that will protect their mark in all countries simultaneously.

C) The company can obtain trademark protection in other countries at any time, as long as no one else has already been granted the same trademark in those countries for similar goods or services.

D) The company must wait until they have been using the trademark in a foreign country for at least 1 year before applying for protection there.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Unlike patents, there is no specific grace period for filing international trademarks. Companies can seek trademark protection in other countries at any time, provided that no one else has already been granted the same trademark in those countries for similar goods or services. 

Answer A is incorrect because it confuses trademark rules with patent rules. The 12-month grace period applies to patents, not trademarks.

Answer B is incorrect because there is no such thing as a global trademark. Trademarks must be obtained separately in each country where protection is sought.

Answer D is incorrect because there is no requirement to use a trademark in a foreign country for a specific period before applying for protection. In fact, many countries allow you to file for trademark protection based on intent to use.

documentation.title: Should I pay rent, post-lease period, when I didn't live there anymore?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: my friend and I moved out of our apartment a week before our lease was up, but we just simply didn't return the keys or let the apartment complex know, thinking they'd just charge us for it if needed. Now, we are being charged 250 dollars as a prorated amount for the days **after the lease was up** that we didn't let the management know that we had left.

> The rent charge was the pro\-rated rent for every day after 2/27 that the apartment remained in y’alls possession. Unless the keys are turned in or the resident confirms in writing that they have vacated the unit we cannot legally take possession of the apartment. For that reason you were being charged rent until I received the email confirmation from you that y’all have in fact vacated the unit.

Even though it is not a high amount, I am not fully willing to pay it because we weren't there.

I would appreciate any advice.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: When you take possession of someone else's apartment and live there, that means you have an exclusive and protected right to be there and even exclude the owner from entering as he normally could in his own property. You prevent the owner from renting it to someone else. The rent that you pay under the rental contract is what it costs you to gain these privileges. If you leave early, your obligation to pay the amount of the lease still exists, even if you're not there.

If you had told the landlord that you were leaving, returned the key, and he had managed to re\-rent the unit before the end of your lease by a couple of days, then he might have be obligated (depending on local law) to take those days into account.

15.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A tenant moves out of their apartment 5 days before their lease expires but doesn't inform the landlord or return the keys. The landlord charges the tenant for 10 days of rent after the lease expiration. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this situation?

A) The tenant is not responsible for any charges after the lease expiration date, regardless of when they moved out or informed the landlord.

B) The tenant is only responsible for the 5 days remaining on their lease, but not for any days after the lease expiration.

C) The tenant is responsible for all charges until they officially inform the landlord and return the keys, even if this extends beyond the lease expiration date.

D) The landlord is illegally charging the tenant and must immediately refund all charges for days after the lease expiration date.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the documentation, the tenant remains responsible for rent charges until they officially inform the landlord that they have vacated the property and return the keys. This is because the landlord cannot legally take possession of the apartment or re-rent it until they have confirmation that the tenant has moved out. Even if the tenant has physically left the property, their failure to inform the landlord or return the keys means they still technically have possession of the apartment. This obligation can extend beyond the original lease expiration date if the tenant fails to properly communicate their departure and return the keys.

documentation.title: Rental: am I responsible for all maintenance, including that caused by wear and tear, under $200?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: 
> **tl/dr:** My property manager (PM) states that I'm responsible for all maintenance under $200 in the home, regardless of whether it is the result of damage I
>  cause. This is on the basis of a clause in the lease that I find very
>  ambiguous. This also is at odds with my (admittedly non\-expert)
>  understanding of real estate law. Is it possible I'm actually on the
>  hook for repairs clearly caused by standard wear\-and\-tear, and which
>  are not at all my fault?

I just moved into a new rental home and there have been a number of maintenance items that have needed repair, which the owner has paid for. However the property manager has recently stated that we are responsible for *all* maintenance items under $200\. That sounds very much at odds with my understanding of "real estate law" (aka the landlord is always responsible for basic wear and tear), and didn't sound like anything I read in the lease so I looked it over. There are two clauses in the lease related to maintenance:

> **TENANT TO MAINTAIN; USE OF PREMISES;**
> 
> 
> TENANT shall be responsible for the cost of all minor repairs and
>  damages to the PREMISES due to the default, negligence, or willful
>  misconduct of TENANT or TENANT'S family or guests, including \[long
>  list of perfectly reasonable things]. TENANT to alert the LANDLORD to
>  any declining conditions inside and outside of the PREMISES included
>  but not limited to \[another list of things].

This seems perfectly normal and reasonable to me. Farther down it says:

> **Maintenance:** The Tenant agrees to properly maintain the home and complete, at his own expense, all daily maintenance EXCLUDING furnace/AC, water heater, appliance replacement and major repairs. The tenant is responsible for the cleaning of all clogged drain lines. If the home is located within a community governed by a Homeowners Association, Tenant does hereby agree to abide by the rules and bylaws of said Association (*Exceeding $200 maintenance threshold contact owner/landlord*)

(emphasis mine). That last bit \- `Exceeding $200 maintenance threshold contact owner/landlord` \- is what the PM pointed to as establishing that I am responsible for *all* maintenance under $200\. That is not at all how I understood that sentence. The reason is because this is a section talking about *daily maintenance*, i.e. the regular things that need to happen to keep a house running \- changing air filters, light bulbs, snow removal, etc... and that the $200 threshold only applies to items such as these. However the PM believes this means that I'm instead responsible for any maintenance under $200\.

To pick a specific example, the basement just lost all power. An electrician just left and determined that there is a wiring issue in the walls and a new wire needs to be run. From the perspective of the PM, if the electrician charges less than $200 it is my responsibility because of this clause in the lease.

I can't decide if I simply misread this lease because of my own expectations on the division of duties between tenant and landlord (aka the landlord is *always* responsible for all normal wear and tear \- such as a wire breaking somewhere in the walls), or if the PMs understanding of this clause is completely at odds with basic property management law and therefore incorrect. Obviously though I need to figure out which is the case so I know how to respond. If I signed a lease I shouldn't have because I misread an important clause, then I'm going to have to eat this one and let it be the cost of learning an important lesson... So...

**Is my PMs understanding of the situation correct?**

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Bizarrely, it depends on where you live in Kentucky. There is [a law](https://apps.legislature.ky.gov/law/statutes/chapter.aspx?id=39159), the Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (KRS 383\.500 to 383\.705\) which states limits on residential leases (otherwise, the matter would be governed by the terms of the contract and common law). The state didn't enact those laws as enforceable in the state, it "made them available" for cities, counties and urban\-county governments to adopt unmodified (or not). So it depends in part on whether your locale adopted the law. Assuming it did, in the [definitions](https://apps.legislature.ky.gov/law/statutes/statute.aspx?id=35726), 

> (13\)"Security deposit" means an escrow payment made to the landlord
>  under the rental agreement for the purpose of securing the 
>  landlord against financial loss due to damage to the premises 
>  occasioned by the tenant's occupancy **other than ordinary wear
>  and tear**.

(emphasis added)
That would mean that they can't take the cost of carpet cleaning, painting etc. out of your security deposit.

[§383\.595](https://apps.legislature.ky.gov/law/statutes/statute.aspx?id=35736) (again, if applicable) states the obligations of the landlord, so he must

> Maintain in good and safe working order and condition 
>  all electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, ventilating, 
>  air\-conditioning, and other facilities and appliances, including 
>  elevators, supplied or required to be supplied by him

So it depends on whether the URLTA was enacted in your jurisdiction. [This page](http://kyjustice.org/node/708) indicates where that is the law, and also urges you to read the lease.

16.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: In Kentucky, a tenant's responsibility for maintenance costs under $200 as stated in their lease is:

A) Always legally binding, regardless of local laws
B) Never legally binding, as it contradicts state-wide tenant protection laws
C) Dependent on whether the local jurisdiction has adopted the Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (URLTA)
D) Only applicable to daily maintenance tasks like changing light bulbs and air filters

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because in Kentucky, the applicability of landlord-tenant laws can vary by location. The Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (URLTA) was made available for cities, counties, and urban-county governments to adopt, but it's not uniformly enforced across the state. In areas where URLTA has been adopted, it would typically require landlords to maintain electrical systems and other essential facilities, potentially overriding lease clauses that attempt to shift those costs to tenants. However, in areas where URLTA hasn't been adopted, the lease terms might have more weight.

A is incorrect because the lease terms are not always binding if they contradict applicable local laws.

B is incorrect because there is no state-wide law that universally overrides such lease terms; it depends on local adoption of URLTA.

D is incorrect because while this might be a reasonable interpretation of the lease clause, the question is about legal enforceability, not just lease interpretation.

documentation.title: Undertakings have expired - am I allowed to do whatever I want?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Previously I’ve asked question about undertakings 
\- [Non\-molestation \- undertakings \- Legal Aid \- is it possible to appeal?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/30652/non-molestation-undertakings-legal-aid-is-it-possible-to-appeal) \- whether there is a way to dispute them.

*(what I did not realize at the time, it could have been a plot to obtain Legal Aid)*

Back then agreed to not publish on social media. 

These undertakings have now expired.

### (potentially native) understanding:

1. Someone invites me to the court
2. I say OK, no worries, I will comply.
3. Six months period is gone, am I allowed to publish stuff again?

### Alternative approach:

1. If someone commits a crime, they are released on probation.
2. Second time they got caught, they are likely to end up in prison.
3. Third time the penalty is even higher.

---

I made a mistake by not challenging the allegations.

Now as the undertakings have expired, am I allowed to do whatever I want?

Or \- following the crime example \- the next time situation occurs I’m likely to be penalised more?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As I understand it, a court order was made which contained undertakings to the Court. 
Those undertakings were given voluntarily by you to the Court.
The court order would have been sealed (stamped with the Court's seal). 
That gives the undertakings the same status as an injunction. If you do not comply with your undertakings, it's a contempt of court. 

It sounds like the undertakings are/were limited in time, to 6 months duration from the date the undertakings were given or from the date the Order was sealed. 

If that's the case, then they have lapsed, and you are no longer prevented from doing whatever it was that was restrained by the undertakings.

Because the consequences of getting it are so very serious \- you could get yourself locked up \- you should send the Undertakings to a lawyer and ask them for advice. 

That way you'll avoid misunderstandings. 

It all depends on the precise wording of the Court Order.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A person agreed to undertakings in court, including not publishing on social media for a period of 6 months. Now that the 6-month period has expired, what is the most accurate statement about their situation?

A) They are free to do whatever they want without any potential legal consequences.
B) They are still bound by the undertakings indefinitely.
C) They are no longer bound by the specific undertakings, but should be cautious about future actions.
D) They must apply to the court for permission to resume the previously restricted activities.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Once the undertakings have expired after the specified 6-month period, the person is no longer legally bound by those specific restrictions. However, they should still be cautious about their future actions for several reasons:

1. The expiration of undertakings doesn't erase the original issues that led to them.
2. If similar situations arise in the future, courts may view repeated behavior more severely.
3. The person made a mistake by not challenging the original allegations, which could affect future legal proceedings.
4. While they're technically free to resume previously restricted activities, doing so immediately or without consideration could potentially lead to new legal issues.

Answer A is incorrect because it doesn't account for potential future consequences. Answer B is wrong because the undertakings were time-limited. Answer D is incorrect because court permission is not typically required after undertakings expire, though seeking legal advice would be prudent.

documentation.title: Is it illegal to alter your boarding pass?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So the problem is my legal gender on my id is non\-binary ("X"), but the airline (Frontier) only allows you to choose male or female. I went around in circles with their customer support and their supervisor on this for hours and got nowhere with them. As a result my boarding pass gender and my ID gender are not going to match. I'm worried that TSA either A) won't let me through or B) will demand a ~~free grope~~ patdown because my gender information won't match. Would it be illegal for me to simply pre\-print my boarding pass to PDF, edit the gender to match my ID, and then print it out to bring with me?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I recognize your difficulty, and I'm not sure about the formal legality of it (which would go to the materiality of the alteration, which if material would probably be a presentation of a false document to a TSA officer).

But more practically, when you present your boarding pass and ID to the TSA officer before going through security, their system checks your boarding pass against the boarding pass in the computer system. If those don't match, you are sent back to the ticketing desk.

My wife and I had to do this on a recent trip simply because folding up our boarding passes to put them in my wallet caused smudging that was enough to cause the TSA system to conclude that our boarding passes weren't in the system. This also triggered heightened bag searches and pat down searches for both of us going through security the second time around.

In your shoes, I'd try my chances with a TSA officer accepting the ID v. boarding pass mismatch with your brief explanation instead. Due to the limitations of airline software, discrepancies between IDs and boarding passes are common enough for reasons like the inability of airline software to handle two word surnames, very short surnames, hyphens, and apostrophes.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A non-binary individual with an "X" gender marker on their ID is booking a flight with an airline that only allows "male" or "female" gender options. Concerned about potential issues at TSA checkpoints, they consider editing their boarding pass to match their ID. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate and legally sound course of action?

A) Edit the PDF of the boarding pass to change the gender marker to "X" before printing it out
B) Contact the airline's corporate office to demand they update their system to include non-binary options
C) Proceed with the mismatched information and explain the situation to the TSA officer if questioned
D) Choose not to fly with this airline and find an alternative method of transportation

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Option C is the most appropriate and legally sound course of action. Editing the boarding pass (Option A) could be considered presenting a false document to a TSA officer, which may have legal consequences. While contacting the airline's corporate office (Option B) might be a good long-term solution, it doesn't solve the immediate problem. Choosing not to fly (Option D) is an extreme reaction that unnecessarily inconveniences the traveler.

The documentation suggests that discrepancies between IDs and boarding passes are relatively common due to various limitations in airline software. TSA officers are likely familiar with such issues. Proceeding with the mismatched information and providing a brief explanation if questioned allows the traveler to be honest and transparent while still attempting to complete their journey. This approach avoids potential legal issues and gives the TSA officer the opportunity to use their discretion in handling the situation.

documentation.title: How to know if a contract is enforceable or "void"?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I read, for example, that specific cryptographic smart contracts are "not enforceable" in the legal context of them, and I understand that an agreement or a contract between parties that includes doing something illegal is void as well or "non\-enforceable." If Peter signs a contract to give up his human rights, that contract would also be void, and probably the same for equality in many situations. But is there a general idea of how to know, or is it as simple as the idea of "non\-disponible law" (not sure of the English word for it), which means some laws that hold no matter what the agreement has been made between two parties? In Sweden for example, the law of an individual, not representing an organization, who purchases something from a commercial company, cannot have rights that are less favorable than in the law of consumer (Kkl, konsumentköplagen), whereas between two commercial companies buying and selling something between them. Any agreement (within what is legal to do) will hold and enforceable according to "köplagen" (law of buying).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [common\-law](/questions/tagged/common-law "show questions tagged 'common-law'")

This is a broad question. You are basically asking for the content of several months of an introductory contracts course focused on the elements of contract formation and grounds for voidability. The best an answer can do at this point is to briefly list the factors that would have to be considered when trying to assess whether a contract exists, is enforceable, or is voidable. There are many other questions and answers on this site that get into the specifics of each of these.

1. Was the contract even formed?

	* was there an offer
	* was there acceptance
	* was there consideration
	* was there intention to create legal relations
2. Are there reasons why the contract would be void?

	* public policy grounds
	* a party lacked capacity
	* illegality
	* statutory overrides (like commercial codes or consumer protection acts)
3. Are there reasons why one party can void and rescind the contract or can ask the court for relief in the form of equitable rescission ([the dividing line between these is debated and differs between jurisdiction](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/87577/in-the-u-k-is-rescission-due-to-mere-misrepresentation-an-entitlement-or-is-i/87591#87591))

	* mistake
	* fraud
	* duress
	* misrepresentation
	* others ...

I am almost certainly not covering all the possible ways that a contract might fail to exist or be void or voidable, and I don't intend to; this is meant only to give you a sense of the kinds of things that would go into the analysis. I have approached this through a common\-law (and equity) lens as opposed to civil law, but even within the common\-law world, there are differences between jurisdictions.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following scenarios would most likely result in an enforceable contract under common law principles?

A) Alice and Bob sign a contract where Bob agrees to sell illegal drugs to Alice in exchange for money.

B) Carol, who is 16 years old, enters into a contract to buy a car from a dealership without her parents' consent.

C) David and Emma sign a contract where Emma agrees to provide graphic design services for David's business in exchange for payment.

D) Frank signs a contract under duress, agreeing to sell his house to George for half its market value.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) is not enforceable because it involves illegal activity.
B) is likely voidable because Carol, as a minor, may lack the capacity to enter into a contract.
C) appears to meet the basic requirements for a valid contract: offer, acceptance, consideration, and intention to create legal relations, without any obvious grounds for voidability.
D) is voidable due to duress, which is a factor that can allow a party to rescind a contract.

Option C is the most likely to result in an enforceable contract as it doesn't present any clear issues with contract formation or grounds for voidability.

documentation.title: Protecting self from unknowingly posting copyrighted material
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Someone is getting me to make them a Facebook page. They are giving me the material. They also want me to edit (Photoshop) some images for them. I'm worried that I may be breaking copyright. If I get them to sign a contract agreeing that all material they provide me, they own the copyright for, and they agree to indemnify me, are these two things enough to protect me if someone makes a claim that I posted copyrighted material? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Copyright Primer
----------------

If **you** make a copy (or a derivative work like a Photoshopped photo) of a copyrighted work without the commercial copyright owner's permission then **you** are *prima facie* guilty of copyright infringement. Further, if you do not give attribution to or deal in a derogatory way with the holder of any moral copyright, you are breaching their rights as well. The commercial and moral copyright holder(s) may or may not be the same people.

If you are alleged to have infringed copyright you may be able to avail yourself of a fair dealing/use defense, however, in the circumstances you describe this is unlikely to be successful. Basically, what you are describing is **not** fair dealing/use.

It is unlikely that what you are proposing would be considered *criminal* infringement so you would not be subject to criminal sanctions like gaol time or fines.

You are open to being sued by the copyright (commercial and/or moral) holder.
